comment.author: 42264328@N00
comment._content: Two notable Native Americans mentioned in the Wikipedia article on this event are Red Hawk of the Sioux and Two Moons of the Cheyenne. There are several photos of Red Hawk on the Internet, including one from the LOC. I am not sure if either of them are shown in this photo. Seems like there should be photos with complete captions somewhere, such as in the New York Times. The date of the dedication is given by the Wikipedia article as "On a rainy Washington's Birthday in 1913". At that time, that was celebrated on 22 February, the actual birthday, so the date of this would appear to be 22 February 1913.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content:
cotinis:

Thanks again for the additional information. We will update the descriptive data to add more details about the dedication and hope to uncover more definitive identifications of the Native Americans shown here.

comment.author: 16909288@N00
comment._content: The men featured in the image are not Sioux.  They appear to be from a rocky mountain tribe to the west of where the Sioux lived.  The floral motif in the beadwork gives it away as the Sioux were famous for their "lazy" stitch which was rigidly geometric.  The drooping breast plates are common among the Crow (Absarokee), a tribe that lived in the plains and mountains--fierce enemies of the Sioux (Lakota).  However these men lack the Crow hairstyle which included a distinctive bang .

comment.author: 37623106@N06
comment._content: This picture is of three Crow Chiefs. From left to right, Whiteman runs him, Plenty Coup, Medicine Crow. Whiteman runs him is my great great grandfather. I am a direct decendent of Whiteman runs him. He was the War Chief and Lead Scout for Custer during the Battle of the Little Big Horn. And he was chosen to be the model for the statue that Rodman Wanamaker had invisioned. He was molded in plaster in his full regalia, and I am searching for any infomation leading to finding that mold. I can be contacted at cjaystewart92@yahoo.com

comment.author: 34997905@N03
comment._content: Thanks for the identifications, cjaystewart92. I'll forward to cataloging staff to verify and make possible corrections to the catalog records.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: The New York Times story about the arrival of the Indians at Penn Station on 2/21/13, together with a description of the planned ceremony. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C06E4D61E3AE633A... "CHIEFS OF DYING RACE HERE FOR HONORS; Noted Red Men Arrive from the West to Attend the Unveiling of a Statue to Their Ancestors" The medal given by Wanamaker to Red Hawk to commemorate the occasion is in this museum's online collection: www.beloit.edu/logan_online/collections/catalogue/north_a...
